content.rendered:
Today is National Common Courtesy Day, and it is observed each year on November 21. There are several ways that you can participate.

  • Send a note to a friend or loved one.
  • Do household chores that you normally wouldn’t do.
  • Give someone flowers.
  • Rake someone’s yard.
  • Pick up trash on a walk.
  • Say “thank you” to the person who bags your groceries.
  • Say “hi” to a stranger.
  • Say “please” when you ask for something.
  • Use your manners when eating a meal.
  • Hold the door open for someone else.

There are several ways to show common courtesy. And we could all think of a few. Unfortunately, it’s all too easy to miss at least some opportunities because, it seems, we are all so busy. If we’re not running to the next major event, we’re answering a text or checking social media. It seem “safer” to stay busy with social media than to risk putting ourselves out there to help others.

It’s called “Common Courtesy” because it probably was more common. There was no social media to lean on, and there probably weren’t as many things that “had to be done.” But when we realize all that God has done for us, courtesy is something that we want to show, common or not.

Even in the past, common courtesy was something that had to be learned. We aren’t born with this trait. In fact, when we are young, we tend to focus on our own needs. We must not only be told to be courteous, but we must see someone else be courteous. If someone tells us to be courteous and they themselves are rude, we’re not likely to “do as they say.”

Remember to show courtesy, and not only today, especially if little ones are watching. And don’t just be courteous out where others can see you. Common courtesy begins in the home.
